channel.title: Comments on: SQL Advent 2011 Day 9: Dynamic TOP
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.description: Minor point of correction. You say SQL2005+ but you show code like this: "DECLARE @t INT = 30". With SQL2005, you cannot declare a variable and assign it a value like this. You need to use 2 statements. You can do this on one like, but it still must be 2 statements, like this: "Declare @t int; Set @t = 30;"
item.content:encoded: Minor point of correction. You say SQL2005+ but you show code like this: “DECLARE @t INT = 30”. With SQL2005, you cannot declare a variable and assign it a value like this. You need to use 2 statements. You can do this on one like, but it still must be 2 statements, like this: “Declare @t int; Set @t = 30;”

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Simon, you are right, I will update the post to reflect that
item.content:encoded: Simon, you are right, I will update the post to reflect that

item.title: By: Simon
item.dc:creator: Simon
item.content:encoded:
> As you might know, SET ROWCOUNT has been deprecated and it should not be used anymore.

It is only deprecated* for for DELETE, INSERT, and UPDATE statements. SELECT statements are where it is most often used, like above.

* Actually, MSDN does not even use that word.
